note.p: Encasing the first line of the title, a rectangle is drawn in pencil, which includes scrolls or leaf ornaments, as if imitating a cartouche. The numeral 2 on opposite ends of the rectangle also appear intended to contribute to the ornamentation.
In light pencil below the caption, Ruskin practiced writing the word going.
Justification mark (MS I)—See Editorial and Encoding Rationale and Methodology: Element, Attribute, and Value Usage—Justification, Runover, and Word Division.

Unidentified mark (MS I)—The meaning of the superscript character between the l and the s is obscure. Perhaps Ruskin started to form an apostrophe but stopped as he realized his error in making a plural into a possessive.

Unidentified punctuation mark (MS I)—Throughout MS III, in volume two of "Harry and Lucy" as well as in "The Monastery", Ruskin punctuates using a combination of two points and what might be an apostophe or a single quatation mark or a comma above the baseline--or possibly none of these appearances.
